snippet: A recent letter from FEMA to 142,000 homeowners acknowledged that its procedures may have been seriously flawed, and that they may be eligible for additional payment. But the storm victims have been hesitant to face more red tape.
abstract: Only around 11,000 of 142,000 homeowners who filed flood insurance claims in wake of Hurricane Sandy have asked Federal Emergency Management Agency to review their cases, option offered after it was revealed that initial reviews may have been flawed; response confirms fears of elected officials in New York and New Jersey that homeowners have been discouraged from seeking money they are owed by severely flawed bureaucratic process.
lead_paragraph: A recent letter from FEMA to 142,000 homeowners acknowledged that its procedures may have been seriously flawed, and that they may be eligible for additional payment. But the storm victims have been hesitant to face more red tape.

headline.main: Hurricane Sandy’s Red Tape Makes a Veteran Say, ‘I’d Rather Go Back to Falluja’
headline.print_headline: Hurricane Sandy’s Red Tape: ‘I’d Rather Go Back to Falluja’
